channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Dissidents Are Detained
item.description: The Cuban police detained several dissidents on Tuesday and thwarted an unauthorized political protest in the most significant crackdown on the opposition since Cuba and the United States agreed this month to normalize ties.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Searchers Pull AirAsia Plane Debris and Bodies From Java Sea
item.description: Rescue teams off the coast of Borneo found bodies and debris from the AirAsia plane that disappeared Sunday, but it remained unknown why the plane went down.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Putin's Way: How Putin Forged a Pipeline Deal That Derailed
item.description: Russia’s energy minister and its energy giant, Gazprom, helped shape a Bulgarian bill for a pipeline that President Vladimir V. Putin sought to keep Europe dependent on Russian gas.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and JO BECKER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin used Aleksei B. Miller, Gazprom’s leader, left, to press Bulgaria for a pipeline.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prison Sentence for Maker of Documentary on Chinese Constitutional Rule
item.description: The filmmaker, Shen Yongping, was detained in April and formally arrested on June 4, the 25th anniversary of the military crackdown on student-led protesters in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic, Is Spared Prison in a Fraud Case, but His Brother Is Jailed
item.description: Mr. Navalny was not jailed despite violating house arrest by trying to join an antigovernment rally. But in what was widely seen as the Kremlin punishing him, his brother Oleg was sentenced to three and a half years in prison in the fraud case.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny was not imprisoned despite violating house arrest, but his brother was.

item.title: Court Orders Arrest of Ex-Executive at Korean Airlines Over ‘Nut Rage’
item.description: Cho Hyun-ah, daughter of the airline’s chairman, may face charges of assaulting the crew of a flight she disrupted.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Journalists surrounded Cho Hyun-ah, a former Korean Airlines executive, at a court in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Calls to Free Leading Cleric in Bahrain
item.description: Sheikh Ali Salman, who is the head of the main Shiite opposition al-Wefaq party, was taken into custody on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sony Attack, First a Nuisance, Swiftly Grew Into a Firestorm
item.description: Interviews suggest that Sony — slow to realize the depths of its peril — let its troubles deepen by mounting a public defense only after enormous damage had been done.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: A Hollywood billboard for Sony Pictures’ “The Interview” was removed on Dec. 18, after the studio canceled its theatrical run.

item.title: Merkel to Attack Anti-Immigrant Movement in Germany
item.description: The German chancellor will use her New Year’s speech to urge people not to join the weekly protests in Dresden held by Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the West.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel arriving at a European Union leaders summit in Brussels on Dec. 18.

item.title: Drone Strike Is Said to Kill Shabab Leader
item.description: The American strike in Somalia killed the chief of intelligence for the Shabab, the Qaeda affiliate, Somali officials said. American officials have not identified the target.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Resolution for Palestinian State Fails in United Nations Security Council
item.description: A draft resolution to set a deadline to establish a sovereign Palestinian state failed to receive the nine votes that were needed for adoption in the 15-member Council.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Norwegians Turn Ambivalent on Statoil, Their Economic Bedrock
item.description: Though oil and gas provide a quarter of Norway’s G.D.P., concern over climate change is fracturing the country’s bond with its flagship company.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:description: The Statoil-operated Snoehvit liquefied natural gas plant on Melkoeya island, Norway. The company is coming under pressure for the environmental damage caused by the oil and gas it produces.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Militants Attack Town
item.description: Gunmen opened fire in a town in northeast Nigeria, killing at least 15 people, witnesses and a security source said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Murder Rate Soars
item.description: Homicides in El Salvador jumped by 56 percent this year as a truce between its most powerful street gangs crumbled, the authorities said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Bomber Targets Parliament
item.description: A suicide bomber detonated a car laden with explosives on Tuesday in front of a hotel where Libya’s Parliament was in session in the eastern city of Tobruk.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Man Kills Eight in Alberta and Then Commits Suicide, Police Say
item.description: A man killed eight people, including two young children, in a “senseless mass murder” in Alberta before committing suicide, the Edmonton police chief, Rod Knecht, said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By KAYNE ROGERS

item.title: Sierra Leone Journal: Ebola Ravages Economies in West Africa
item.description: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Source of Ebola Outbreak in West Africa Might Be Bats, Study Says
item.description: Scientists have traced the origins of the current epidemic to a toddler in Guinea who died last year and think he may have caught the virus from bats in a tree near his village.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Aleksei Navalny and Russia’s Protesters Face a Tough Battle
item.description: Apathy is the greatest threat to the Russian opposition.
item.dc:creator: By EMILY PARKER

item.title: A Veteran’s Chemical Burns Expanded Military Doctors’ Knowledge, but His Care Faltered
item.description: An Air Force staff sergeant’s wounding by a chemical round led the Army to urge lifelong monitoring of such cases, but he says he was not tracked after retiring.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Daniel Mould, a former staff sergeant in an explosive ordnance disposal team, was wounded by a recovered chemical round in Delaware in 2004.
